awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Reducing Emissions and Cost in the Production of Conventional Cementitious Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce cost and environmental impact associated with Portland cement, the most common general-purpose cement.  A new process for making Portland cement has not been introduced in nearly 100 years, and its production accounts for for 5.5% of global greenhouse gas emissions, with 60% from the rock and the remainder from the fuel used in the process. This project proposes a different process that can reduce emissions. 

Currently cement is made via the thermal decomposition of limestone to produce lime and CO2. This project advances a technology based on selective extraction of calcium from non-carbonate rocks for conversion into cement. The process also produces amorphous silica as a byproduct. Because calcium is not associated with carbonate, the emissions associated with manufacturing process are reduced.  This  research will be focused on thermal decomposition of the calcium-bearing compound in the process stream to make calcium silicates as a basis for the cement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Brimstone Energy, Inc. is a venture-backed R&D company targeting the reduction of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by eliminating the CO2 footprint from the cement manufacturing process, accounting for ~8% of global CO2 emissions. It accomplishes this via two inextricably linked strategies. First, the Company has developed a process for producing carbon-neutral/-negative ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) and supplementary cementitious materials (SCM), the primary ingredient in concrete and related materials. Second, the Brimstone process produces a by-product, magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)2), that, when exposed to air or seawater, absorbs and sequesters CO2. Unlike other efforts to replace OPC with a low- or zero-carbon substitute, Brimstone is changing the way OPC is manufactured, thus assuring an immediate large-scale market for its product.


At the core of the OPC manufacturing operation is a patented chemical leaching process that extracts minerals from silicate rock and then converts them into the material constituents needed for making OPC and SCM. This process is a critical step to realizing three important elements of Brimstone?s process: 1) cement clinker composition; 2) SCM quality/composition; and 3) a closed-loop, leaching agent regeneration cycle allowing the process to be economical.

The Phase I project had four primary goals: 

1) Achieve >90% calcium leach yield; 90% or greater Ca extraction was accomplished under a variety of conditions. The experimental procedures, involving eight different process variables, indicated that the highest impact parameters were the leaching acid wt%, pulp density and filling. Leaching time was also a critical parameter, but only after the range of times were increased 5-fold. Of course, longer leaching times represent a cost challenge in that they increase the contribution of CapEx and OpEx on a per sample basis. Our ASPEN model showed that we can make the process economical up to 48 hours of leaching  time and with efficiencies as low as 70%.

2) Produce amorphous silica (SCM);  The leach solution from #1 was vacuum filtered and the residue collected, with the expectation that it was primarily amorphous silica. Upon testing, The silica product produced passed both standards for Fly ash and silica fume, two very common SCM components.

3) Precipitate Mg, Al, Ca, and Fe: The procedures were successful at precipitating 100% of Al and Fe and around 90% of Mg with some trials at close to 100%. The procedures were less successful at precipitating the Ca. Modifications to the process are underway and preliminary experiments look promising.

4) Decompose Ca salts and produce ordinary portland cement:  Initial attempts appear to have been successful as determined by the presence of C3S (tri-calcium silicate) and C2S (di-calcium silicate) in the product material. The presence of both of these in the proper ratio is indicative of ordinary portland cement. 

In conclusion, Brimstone Energy has made significant progress towards its goals of efficient and economic conversion of silicate rock into ordinary portland cement. It has made progress in each of the four areas of focus in this Phase I SBIR: 1) Chemical leaching of minerals from Silicate rock; 2) production of ASTM-grade Fly Ash and Silica Fume; 3) precipitation of Ca, Mg, Al and Fe compounds for subsequent addition to the clinker mix; and 4) fabrication of OPC. Each of these areas requires further refinement in a more comprehensive manner that will be the subject of a Phase II proposal. 

Given the higher abundance of the raw material feedstock, the potential for lower cost, and the carbon-negative footprint of the process, the positive impacts of successfully commercializing Brimstone?s innovative OPC process are enormous. The technology can both be implemented as a retrofit in existing OPC/concrete operations and in new cement production operations. The latter is especially important in that growth in cement production is somewhat limited by carbon concerns and the availability of traditional SCM, which often is sourced from carbon-intensive industries such as fly-ash from coal plants or slag from steel plants. Brimstone?s process produces high-quality SCM in conjunction with its clinker, and thus the demand for high-carbon content SCM is eliminated. The gross impact could range from a low of 0.4 Gt with a 10% market share, to a high that is nearly double ~4 Gt for the entire cement industry if thermal processes are driven by renewable energy and all of the by-product Mg(OH)2 is used for direct air or ocean capture of CO2 for permanent sequestration.
